Issues.Title: Default value for "ToolTip.AutoPopDelay" causes infinite tooltip (on Win 11 24H2 only?)
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

The sample targets .NET Framework 4.8. NET6 and .NET8 - the problem happens for all of them. Same for .NET 9.


### Did it work in .NET Framework?

No

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

_No response_

### Issue description

The default value for "ToolTip.AutoPopDelay" causes an infinite tooltip that never goes away (tested on two systems). 
If I change it to 4999 or 5001, it works as expected and the tooltip is hidden after the delay.

The [doc](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.windows.forms.tooltip.autopopdelay?view=windowsdesktop-8.0) does not say anything about this. But it also says "The maximum time you can delay a popup is 5000 milliseconds", which is probably also wrong, as the value 10000 works as expected.


Maybe related to the OS version (Win 11 24H2, verified on two machines)? I tested the .NET 4.8 version of my sample also with Windows Server 2019, and here the tooltip is closed after 5 seconds.

### Steps to reproduce

See attached sample: [ToolTipTest.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21742135/ToolTipTest.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Default value for "ToolTip.AutoPopDelay" causes infinite tooltip (on Win 11 24H2 only?)" (#13800)

Issues.Title: ToolStripButton does not visually distinguish between Checked and Indeterminate states
Issues.Body: ### .NET version .NET 10.0 SDK build: 10.0.100-rc.1.25412.107 ### Did it work in .NET Framework? No ### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+? No ### Issue description `ToolStripButton` supports three check states: `Unchecked`, `Checked`, and `Indeterminate`. However, the visual appearance of the `Checked `and `Indeterminate `states is nearly identical in most themes and renderers, including `ToolStripSystemRenderer` and `ToolStripProfessionalRenderer`. This makes it difficult or impossible for users to distinguish the two states by looking at the UI. Classic mode: Dark mode: ### Steps to reproduce 1. Add a ToolStripButton to a ToolStrip 2. Set CheckOnClick = true and CheckState = Indeterminate 3. Toggle between Checked and Indeterminate states in runtime 4. Observe the UI â€“ no meaningful visual difference between the two states
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "ToolStripButton does not visually distinguish between Checked and Indeterminate states" (#13804)

Issues.Title: Survey - 2025 Repo Survey
Issues.Body:
Hi all,

Over the last few years we've been doing annual surveys to see how well we're doing engaging with the community. This year I'm quite a bit behind schedule, but here is the survey [link](https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/TZHNJ2W). If you would be so kind as to take a few minutes to fill this out we would greatly appreciate your feedback!

~Merrie and the whole WinForms team
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Survey - 2025 Repo Survey" (#13806)

Issues.Title: Remove experimental state for DarkMode
Issues.Body:
## Removing Experimental Status for Dark Mode
We are preparing to remove the experimental flag from Dark Mode in WinForms.

A broad range of customers with diverse applications have tested Dark Mode, helping us reach the quality bar we aimed for and strengthening our confidence in removing its experimental status.

### Important Considerations

WinForms is built as a managed wrapper around native Win32 controls. This architecture introduces inherent limitations in how theming and rendering behave, especially in Dark Mode. While Windows continues to evolve its support for theming, some constraints remain:

- **Rendering Limitations:** Certain controls may not render perfectly in Dark Mode due to the underlying Win32 behavior. These imperfections are expected and will not be treated as bugs.
- **Security and Compatibility First:** We prioritize security and backward compatibility over perfect visual fidelity. Changes that risk breaking classic rendering or introduce regressions will be avoided.
- **Ongoing Improvements:** As Windows improves Win32 theming, WinForms will adapt accordingly. You can expect Dark Mode rendering to improve over time, but not all issues will be resolved immediately.
- **Contrast and A11Y Edge Cases:** Some edge cases may result in suboptimal contrast or fail to meet certain, specific A11Y guidelines. While dark mode for many users addresses one major A11Y concern (general bright screens with too much strain to the eyes): If your application requires strict contrast compliance, we recommend using either Classic (light) mode or High Contrast mode.

## Summary

Dark Mode in WinForms is stable and ready for broader use, but it is not perfect or does not apply to every control area. We ask developers to understand the trade-offs involved and to plan accordingly. 

This issue tracks the PR that will remove the experimental flag and formalize Dark Mode as a supported feature.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Remove experimental state for DarkMode" (#13805)

Issues.Title: CommandParameter property: Provide designer support and control CodeDOM serialization
Issues.Body:
Fixes #13801.

Affected Controls are

- `ButtonBase`
- `ToolStripItem`

Fixes:
- `CommandParameter` is now shown in the property browser, and string values can be directly entered.
- If `CommandParameter` is effectively of type `string`, the values are getting CodeDOM-serialized and -deseriaslized.

 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/13802)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "CommandParameter property: Provide designer support and control CodeDOM serialization" (#13802)

Issues.Title: Designer doesn't show CommandParameter property in PropertyGrid and doesn't serialize its value, even if they are of type string.
Issues.Body:
### .NET version

.NET 7 - .NET 10

### Did it work in .NET Framework?

Yes

### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+?

Was introduced in .NET 7 - doesn't apply.

### Issue description

You cannot find the `CommandParameter` property of a respective control which provides it in the property browser at Design time. The `CommandParameter` can only be _bound_ to a data source's property.

### Steps to reproduce

* Place a Button on a .NET 7+ WinForms App on the Form.
* Try to find the `CommandParameter` property in the PropertyGrid.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Designer doesn't show CommandParameter property in PropertyGrid and doesn't serialize its value, even if they are of type string." (#13801)

Issues.Title: [Dark Mode] The color contrast of selected list Item's Back color and Border color is insufficient
Issues.Body: ### .NET version .NET 10 SDK build: 10.0.100-rc.1.25401.103 ### Did it work in .NET Framework? Not tested/verified ### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+? Occurs when DarkMode feature involved ### Issue description When the application is in Dark Mode, the color contrast of selected list Item's Back color and Border color is insufficient. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Create a WinForms .NET Core application with ListView control 2. Add some items for listview control 3. Enable DarkMode as below in Program.cs file ``` #pragma warning disable WFO5001 Application.SetColorMode(SystemColorMode.Dark); #pragma warning restore WFO5001 ``` 4. Build and run the application 5. Selected the list item, and then using the Accessibility Insight tool to observe the color contrast between selected list Item's Back color and Border color
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Dark Mode] The color contrast of selected list Item's Back color and Border color is insufficient" (#13778)

Issues.Title: Dark Mode: The NumeircUpdown/DomainUpdown have incorrect background color when setting the ReadOnly = True
Issues.Body: ### .NET version .NET SDK 10.0.100-rc.1.25410.103 ### Did it work in .NET Framework? No ### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+? There have improvement after merged the PR: https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/13747 ### Issue description The NumericUpDown/DomainUpdown have incorrect background color when setting the ReadOnly = True in DarkMode: **DarkMode:** **Classic Mode:** ### Steps to reproduce 1. Create Winforms .NET application with targeting .NET 10 2. Add NumericUpDown/DomainUpdown controls in form designer, and setting the ReadOnly = True 3. Set app under Dark mode in program.cs file: ``` #pragma warning disable WFO5001 Application.SetColorMode(SystemColorMode.Dark); #pragma warning restore WFO5001 ``` 4. Build and run project
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Dark Mode: The NumeircUpdown/DomainUpdown have incorrect background color when setting the ReadOnly = True" (#13781)

Issues.Title: Dark Mode: RichTextBox with RTF Text is hard to visible
Issues.Body: ### .NET version .NET SDK 10.0.100-rc.1.25410.103 ### Did it work in .NET Framework? Doesn't apply. ### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+? The issue also can reproduce on .NET 9.0 ### Issue description When using `RichTextBox` to display RTF content in Dark Mode, the text is not easily readable because it blends into the dark background. However, in Classic Mode, the text is displayed correctly. The issue appears to be related to the default text color not being visible on a dark background in Dark Mode. Dark mode: Classic mode: ### Steps to reproduce 1. Create Winforms .NET application with targeting .NET 10 with `RichTextBox `control 2. Assign RTF content to the `RichTextBox `(e.g., "Hello, **World!**" with bold formatting) ``` string rtfText = "{\\rtf1\\ansi\\ansicpg1252\\deff0\\nouicompat\\deflang1033{\\fonttbl{\\f0\\fnil\\fcharset0 Calibri;}}\\viewkind4\\uc1 \\pard\\sa200\\sl276\\slmult1\\f0\\fs22\\lang9 Hello, \\b World\\b0 !\\par}"; richTextBox1.Rtf = rtfText; ``` 3. Set project under Dark mode in program.cs file: ``` #pragma warning disable WFO5001 Application.SetColorMode(SystemColorMode.Dark); #pragma warning restore WFO5001 ``` 4. Build and run project to observe
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Dark Mode: RichTextBox with RTF Text is hard to visible" (#13782)

Issues.Title: Broken rendering with BackgroundImage and transparent BackColor
Issues.Body: ### .NET version .NET 5.0 - .NET 9.0 ### Did it work in .NET Framework? Yes ### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+? Works in .NET Framework and .NET Core 3.x ### Issue description Set a background image and transparent background for a non-root level container object, such as a `GroupBox` or a `Panel`, and add child controls to it. While the background image offset is applied correctly to the child controls, this is not true for the 'foreground' content of the parent, which is reflected in every child control with an incorrect origin. It apparently affects system rendering only (i.e. when `FlatStyle` is `System`), or when a control has no `FlatStyle` (e.g. a `Panel`). Consider the example below: Designer: Rendering in .NET Framework: Rendering in .NET Core/.NET: (Note the "ghost" group boxes appearing in the panel and other controls. The image itself is rendered correctly in the children even if they are over a more colorful area.) ### Steps to reproduce See the attachment: [BackgroundImageIssue.zip](https://github.com/user-attachments/files/21613643/BackgroundImageIssue.zip)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Broken rendering with BackgroundImage and transparent BackColor" (#13784)

Issues.Title: Fix transparent rendering with parents that have a background image
Issues.Body:
If a Graphics backing HDC has an offset origin (SetViewportOrgEx), drawing with a texture brush will reset it. Getting the HDC and releasing it will restore the offset.

Add a few helper methods to HDC to make debugging this sort of thing easier.

Fixes #13784
 ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/13797)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "Fix transparent rendering with parents that have a background image" (#13797)

Issues.Title: Fix title bar small icon scaling
Issues.Body: We weren't actually scaling the icon for the main form. In addition, we didn't have an embedded icon with multiple resolutions. This appropriately sets the right sized icon to eliminate or reduce blurring. At 200% fixed, vs. before: ###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](https://microsoft.github.io/open-pr/?codeflow=https://github.com/dotnet/winforms/pull/13787)

Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "[main] Source code updates from dotnet/dotnet" (#13783)

Issues.Title: [Dark Mode] The color contrast for selected DataGridViewTextBox is insufficient
Issues.Body: ### .NET version .NET 10 SDK build: 10.0.100-rc.1.25401.103 ### Did it work in .NET Framework? Not tested/verified ### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+? Occurs when DarkMode feature involved ### Issue description When the application is in Dark Mode, the color contrast of DataGridViewTextBox is insufficient. This issue does not occur in Classic Mode. ### Steps to reproduce 1. Create Winforms .NET application with targeting .NET 10 2. Add a DataGridView control with DataGridViewTextBoxColumn in form designer 3. Set app under Dark mode in program.cs file: ``` #pragma warning disable WFO5001 Application.SetColorMode(SystemColorMode.Dark); #pragma warning restore WFO5001 ``` 4. Build and run project 5. Input something in DataGridViewTextBox, then select this cell 6. Observe the color contrast between selected DataGridViewTextBox's Text color and Back color
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "[Dark Mode] The color contrast for selected DataGridViewTextBox is insufficient" (#13780)

Issues.Title: Dark Mode: The text still is white for Label control with setting the Enable = False & FlatStyle = System in DarkMode
Issues.Body: ### .NET version .NET SDK 10.0.100-rc.1.25410.103 ### Did it work in .NET Framework? No ### Did it work in any of the earlier releases of .NET Core or .NET 5+? The issue also can reproduce on .NET 9.0 ### Issue description The text still is white for Label control with setting the Enable = False & FlatStyle = System in DarkMode ### Steps to reproduce 1. Create Winforms .NET application with targeting .NET 10 2. Add a Label control in form designer, and setting the Enable = False & FlatStyle = System 3. Set app under Dark mode in program.cs file: ``` #pragma warning disable WFO5001 Application.SetColorMode(SystemColorMode.Dark); #pragma warning restore WFO5001 ``` 4. Build and run project **More info:** The issue also can reproduce on Button/CheckBox/RadioButton controls with same configurations.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Dark Mode: The text still is white for Label control with setting the Enable = False & FlatStyle = System in DarkMode" (#13779)
